A series of K-Ce catalysts with different K/(K+Ce) molar ratios are successfully prepared by hydrothermal method, to optimize catalyst diesel particlate filter (CDPF) regeneration efficiency of soot elimination. The K-Ce catalyst is an excellent promoter for soot combustion by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and the KC-0.2 catalyst has the best catalytic activity because proper K ions lead to more oxygen vacancies and improve contact efficiency with soot. This result corresponds well to characterization analysis, such as XRD, SEM and XPS. In a 10%O2/90%N2 atmosphere, the KC-0.2 has the highest average mass loss rate (Wmean ), maximum mass loss rate (Wmax ) and combustion stability index (Rw ). The weight ratios of the soot/KC-0.2 mixture are less than 1:10, making catalytic oxidation easier for the soot. Thermal aging in static air at 600 °C is used to investigate the catalytic stability of KC-0.2, and the TGA results show that KC-0.2 has good stability at temperatures lower than 600 °C. Compare to KC-0.2, the KC-0.2 based mixed catalyst with ZrO2 participation is further prepared by mechanical method and has better catalytic activity because the presence of Zr enhances redox surface sites of catalyst. This facilitates the exploration of novel catalysts through combinatorial catalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Soot combustion K-Ce catalyst Catalytic activity Combinatorial catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Diesel engines are widely used in large machinery and heavy vehicles due to their high- power output, low fuel consumption, high durability [1–4]. The massive emission of complex pollutants, such as soot particles, nitrogen oxides (NOX), hydrocarbons (HC) and carbon monoxide (CO), limits the widespread use of diesel engines [5–7]. In particularly, soot particles have a negative impact on the haze environment and have received a lot of attention [8]. Furthermore, soot particles is able to absorb a large number of heavy metals and organic pollutants on the surface [9], which can then be easily inhaled and caused a variety of diseases [10]. As a result, reducing soot particles emission into the atmosphere is critical. The temperature of the diesel engine exhaust outlet ranges from 200 °C to 400 °C, whereas the temperature of soot particles combustion is 500–600 °C [2, 11, 12]. At the moment, CDPFs containing high activity catalysts can promote soot combustion and achieve passive regeneration [13–15], making them one of the most effective and cost-effective methods of removing soot particles at lower temperatures [16, 17]. The purification of soot particles is inextricably linked to the development and modification of efficient catalysts [18–22]. Therefore, the primary focus of CDPF soot particles elimination is the investigation and evolution of catalysts. Ceria-based catalysts are a popular choice among noble metal catalyst alternatives for catalytic oxidation of soot particles due to their excellent oxygen storage capability and redox potential [23–25]. In recent years, a number of research initiatives have been launched to strengthen the catalytic activity of ceria-based materials, including non-metallic modification, rare earth ion doping, metal modification and noble metal supporting. Guillén-Hurtado et al. [26] remark that Ce0.5Pr0.5O2-δ composition is the most catalytic activity one generated by coprecipitation method in N2/O2 environment, and ceria doping with praseodymium has superior capacity of redox compared to pure ceria. According to Zhu et al. [27] the Ce0.64Mn0.36 catalyst has the best catalytic activity in temperature programmed oxidation tests (TPO) among Ce-Mn-O catalysts manufactured utilizing the coprecipitation method with varied Ce/Mn concentrations. Wang et al. [28] point out that the K-doping improves catalyst to the soot oxidation rate in both CO2/ O2 and N2/O2 atmospheres. Li et al. [29] the passages of active K + species in the cryptomelane structure passages improves the soot combustion process due to the presence. Previous research has found that potassium-doping catalysts have excellent catalytic activity. However, the reaction mechanism for potassium-doping catalysts in the soot combustion process is still limited. In this work, affecting factors and catalytic activity on soot combustion of K-Ce catalysts in N2/O2 atmosphere are studied by TGA. On this basis, mixed catalysts based on potassium cerium are synthesized for further research into catalyzed soot combustion. Characterization techniques such as X-ray diffraction, SEM, XPS analysis and Raman spectra are used to investigate the physicochemical properties of the prepared catalysts. This study demonstrates a method for designing of high-efficiency catalysts, which is laying the theoretical groundwork for the promising K-Ce catalysts and their mixed catalysts in the soot combustion process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and samples preparation All materials used this study are commercially available and are used as received with no further purification. The PU (Degussa GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany) is widely used as a diesel model commercial soot, due to its similar chemical morphology and highly repeatability [30, 31]. The major properties are shown in Table 1 . Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical in China supplies the MnO2, SnO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2 catalysts. Table 2 summarizes the specifications and characteristic parameters of several materials. The K-Ce catalysts are created using a hydrothermal process. Initially, proper amounts of K2CO3 (99.5%, RHAWN) and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.5%, Aladdin) are dissolved in 100 ml of deionized water. After that, the mixture is stirred in a magnetic stirrer at 60 °C for 3 h, and the product is dried at 110 °C for 12 h before being calcined in an air muffle furnace at 550 °C for 3 h. Finally, K-Ce catalysts are produced through careful grinding after cooling at room temperature, where x is the K/(K+Ce) molar ratio of the as-prepared catalyst solution and the values are 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5, respectively. Catalysts for those products are labeled as KC- x (0.1–0.5) correspondingly. K-Ce based mixed catalysts are obtained by improvement mechanical methods. In brief, appropriate amounts of K-Ce precursor and commercial catalyst materials are transferred to a ceramic grinding machine for careful grinding (the mass ration of KC-0.2 to commercial catalyst is 5:1), and then the products are dried at 110 °C for 12 h. Finally, the mixtures are mixed for 10 min with a vortex mixer (VORTEX 3 from IKA, Germany). The mixed catalysts obtained are denoted as a/KC-0.2 (a=MnO2, SnO2, TiO2 and ZrO2). 2.2 Characterizations A Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (Japan, Rigaku) collects X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns from 20° to 80° with a scanning step of 0.02° using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The data for the diffraction are obtained at 40 Kv and 40 mA at a rate of 6°·min−1. A thermo scientific Apreo 2C field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) is used to examine the surface morphologies of the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed on an ESCALAB Xi+ instrument with an Al-Kα working as the excitation, and the binding energy (BE) of all spectra is calibrated by C 1 s at 284.8 eV. Raman spectroscopy (scanning range 200–900 cm−1) is carried out with a laser confocal Raman spectrometer (HORIBA LabRAM HR Evolution) and a 514 nm laser line at 1.5 mW laser power. H2-TPR measurements are carried out on an AutoChem-II 2920 chemical adsorption instrument. The catalysts are then heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in a 40 mL/min flow of 10%H2/90%Ar gas, and the amount of hydrogen consumption is recorded by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). O2-TPD tests are pretreated under 3%O2/97%He gas flow at 50 °C until saturated, and then the catalysts are cleaned with 30 ml/min of He flow. The catalysts are heated to 600 °C with 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests and data analysis The temperature programmed test on a thermogravimetric analyzer (TG209F3, NETZSCH, Germany) for the soot oxidation process is used to investigate the catalytic activities of K-Ce catalysts. Before each test, mixture of catalysts and soot (Printex-U soot by Degussa) with different weight ratios are put in vortex mixer for 15 min to achieve a loose contact. Then, the fixed weight (3 mg) of PU in mixed sample is fed into the alumina crucible (diameter height: 6.8 × 7.4 mm) of thermogravimetric analyzer, and the soot oxidation reaction is carried out using a mixed gas consisting of 90% N2 (protected) and 10% O2 at a flow rate of 100 ml/min. With a ramp rate of 10 °C/min, the experiment reaction temperature ranges from 45 °C to 800 °C, and the mass of sample is determined by continuously recording in response to rising temperature. Taking pure PU for example, the three identified temperatures are as follows: starting temperature Ts , peak temperature Tp and ending temperature Te are shown in Fig. 1 . The two values for average mass loss rate and maximum mass loss rate from the beginning to the end of the reaction, corresponding to Wmean and Wmax , respectively. The combustion stability index (Rw ) [32] can be used as a criterion to compare the catalytic performance of catalysts on soot combustion (1). In general, the higher Wmean, Wmax and Rw , values indicate better overall catalytic performance of soot combustion catalysts [33–36]. (1) R w = 8.5875 × 10 7 × W m a x T s × T p e a k 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of K-Ce catalysts 3.1.1 Textural and morphological properties XRD patterns analysis results of various K molar ratios are shown in Fig. 2 . There are six main diffraction peaks for all the catalysts at 2 θ = 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.4°, 59.1°and 69.5°, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) and (400) of lattice faces of CeO2 (JCPDS 43–1002) [37], respectively. At low K concentration (KC-0.1), no K species are detected on the surface of the catalyst. This can be explained by the fact that the K elements participate into the formation of K-Ce solid solutions or are highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst [38], which is further supported by a slight shift in the d value of plane (111) from 3.1234 for CeO2 to 3.1240 for the solid solution. When the molar ratio of K/(K+Ce) is 0.2 and more, the noticeable diffraction peak of K element is detected at 2θ = 23.6° (111), 29.4° (012), 33.8° (112), 41.1° (221), 46.6° (113) and 31.7° (130), which is corresponding to the peak of KNO3 (JCPDS 71–1558) and K2CO3 (JCPDS 70–0292) [39, 40]. The possible explanation is that the requiring of K elements in the formation of K-Ce solid solutions is limited and other potassium salts are dispersed on the surface of K-Ce solid solutions. Meanwhile, the characteristic peak of CeO2 shifts to the lower 2θ degree after the increasing of K concentration, and the enlarged diagrams are displayed Fig. 2(b). Some K elements are introduced into the CeO2 lattice, causing an increase in the lattice constant due to the larger ion radius of K + (0.133 nm) compared to Ce3+ (0.103 nm) and Ce4+ (0.094 nm) [41]. The phase structure of KC-0.2 demonstrates that the maximum lattice expansion, implies the obvious microstrain of KC-0.2. The phase structures of K-Ce at various K molar ratios are listed in Table 3 . Fig. 3 is the SEM images of the CeO2 and K-Ce catalysts. The various K molar ratios have a significant impact on the morphology of the catalyst. The SEM image of the KC-0.1 catalyst demonstrates that it has an average diameter of about 20–30 nm and no K species are detected on the surface, which is consistent with the XRD results. KC-0.2 and KC-0.5 catalysts have detected K species, and the degree and particle size of agglomeration increase clearly with increasing of K doping. By contrast, the lower or higher of K concentration catalysts that average diameter distributions are not uniform compared to KC-0.2 catalyst. The CeO2 structure of the catalysts is well preserved after K supporting in Fig. 3a-c, with the exception that the surface of the CeO2 becomes collapse when the amount of K supported increases excessively in Fig. 3(d). The external surface uniform pores of KC-0.2 catalysts are positive to soot-catalyst contact, which is critical for catalytic performance [42]. As a result, the morphology characteristics of the KC-0.2 catalyst has a positive effect on the reactivity of the active site. 3.1.2 Chemical properties To study the catalysts surface elemental content and chemical states of Ce and O, XPS measurements are performed over the CeO2, KC-0.1, KC-0.2 and KC-0.5 catalysts as shown in Fig. 4 . In the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 4a), the Ce 3d3/2 (labeled as u) and 3d5/2 (labeled as v) are in the range of 901–917 and 883–899 eV, respectively. Specifically, the peaks tagged with u3 (916.53 eV), u2 (907.13 eV), u (900.77 eV) and v3 (898.26 eV), v2 (888.68 eV), v (882.26 eV) are attributed to Ce4+, whereas the peaks tagged by u1 (903.84 eV) and v1 (885.31 eV) are corresponding to Ce3+ [42]. The three prepared catalysts have lower binding energies than CeO2, owing to an interaction between K and Ce elements and the electron-donor effect of K [38] (Table 4 ). Nevertheless, there are discrepancies in the peak area ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) for four different K molar ratios catalysts. The appearance of Ce3+ is reported to cause the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [37, 42]. Among the catalysts, the peaks area ratios of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) increase first then decrease with the increase of K concentration, and KC-0.2 catalyst has the highest Ce3+ content of 17% in Table 4. This means that the KC-0.2 catalyst has the most oxygen vacancies, making it easier to generate active oxygen species and adsorb oxygen for soot combustion. In the O 1 s spectra (Fig. 4b), surface fitting of the prepared catalysts and CeO2 reveals three peaks tagged with Olat, Ovac and Opad, which are corresponding to lattice oxygen, oxygen vacancy and physically adsorbed oxygen, respectively [43]. Similar to the binding energies of Ce3d peaks, the O 1 s peaks shift to lower binding energy values after K doping, which is due to the electron-donor effect of K [38]. There is an interesting phenomenon when the K content increases: the lattice oxygen content on the catalyst surface gradually decreases while the physical adsorbed oxygen content significantly increases. The cerium concentration in the same mass of K-Ce catalysts decreases with increasing potassium content, resulting the crystallinity of the sample is reduced [44–46]. The CeO2 the charge compensation effect would be indued more oxygen vacancy after K ions entering the CeO2 [41], with the surface of the catalysts agglomerating covered oxygen vacancies when the amount of K supported increased excessively [47]. This result corresponds well to the SEM and XRD results. Therefore, the optimal K/(K+Ce) molar ratio of K-Ce catalysts is 0.2, which percentage of Ovac/(Olat+Ovac+Opad) is 19.75%. The presence of suitable potassium and Ce3+ improves contact efficiency and accelerates oxygen vacancies in the soot combustion process. 3.2 K-Ce catalytic activity measurement 3.2.1 Effect of k concentrations on soot combustion Fig. 5 displays the TG-DTG curves of K-Ce catalysts with various potassium concentrations to promote soot combustion in 10%O2/90%N2 atmosphere with PU/catalyst mixtures at a weight ratio of 1:1. With the employed of K-Ce catalysts, the temperature required for soot oxidation is significantly lower than pure soot oxidation. The DTG profile of PU/KC-0.2 mixtures generally exhibits a sharp peak around 430–460 °C, which indicates a high combustion rate compared with the relatively broadened peak shapes obtained over the other potassium concentration catalysts. The evolutions of Wmean, Wmax and Rw during soot oxidation experiments over K-Ce catalysts in different K concentrations are presented in Fig. 6 . The overall tendency of graph increases firstly and then decreases substantially with the K concentrations increasing, and the highest point occurs when the ratio of K/(K+Ce) is 0.2. The Wmean, Wmax and Rw values of KC-0.2 are 2.02%min−1, 15.29%min−1 and 73 × 10 5, respectively. This can be explained K-doping concentration is able to promote catalyst active component migration to promote catalyze the soot combustion. However, the excessive K in K-Ce catalysts cover the surface active site leads to reduce the catalyst activity, which is well agreement with the consequence of XRD and XPS. The result is confirmed that the appropriate K concentration can better enhancement the ability of the catalyst to activate oxygen under O2/N2 atmosphere. 3.2.2 Effect of PU/KC-0.2 wt ratios on soot combustion Fig. 7 displays the TG-DTG curves and characteristic parameter profiles for various PU/KC-0.2 wt ratios (1:1, 1:5, 1:10, 1:15, 1:20). Ts, Tp , and Te offset obviously to the lower temperature region as the weight ratio of PU/KC-0.2 mixture increases, but when the weight ratio of PU/KC-0.2 is more than 1:10, Ts, Tp , and Te change little. At approximately 450 °C, there is a significant PU reaction peak, and the PU is completely combustion at approximately 500 °C. Following the soot reaction, the TG curves rise with increasing PU/catalyst weight ratios, and the intensity of the rise is proportional to the increase in KC-0.2 wt in mixtures. Because excessive catalyst causes more CO2 adsorption, the product mass expands with the amount of catalyst used [48]. This indicates that the excessive use of KC-0.2 catalyst in the catalytic process caused a minor reaction peak (at approximately 500 °C). The peak at 500 °C can be attributed to the alkali nitrate molten salt capturing CO2 and facilitating the formation of carbonate ions CO3 2− [49] as well as some non-catalytic oxidation increasing relatively [33]. As a result, the PU/catalyst weight ratio should be appropriate in order to optimize the catalytic activity. Fig. 8 compares the weight loss ratio and the combustion stability index in mixtures with different proportions of PU/KC-0.2. The ensemble trend of Fig. 8 shows that as KC-0.2 wt increases, Wmean, Wmax and Rw tends to increase first, then decrease. When the weight ratio of PU/KC-0.2 is 1:10, the Wmean and Wmax are relatively large at 1.84%min−1and 24.63%min−1, respectively. Rw reaches the maximum value at 129.7 × 10 5 when the weight ratio of PU/KC-0.2 is 1:10, which increases of 56% over the mixture in 1:1 wt ratio. When the PU/KC-0.2 ratio is lower than 1:10, the soot combustion is promoted primarily due to an increase in surface oxygen vacancies. When the PU/KC-0.2 ratio exceeds 1:10, the combustion products cannot diffuse in time and the mass transfer resistance increases [50], resulting in increased non-catalytic oxidation. The change in various indexes tends to decrease as the KC-0.2 catalyst proportion is increased, so the catalyst proportion in PU/KC-0.2 mixtures should be less than 1:10. 3.2.3 Stability of KC-0.2 catalysts While K-Ce has good catalytic activity for soot oxidation, it is critical to investigate the stability of thermal aging. Fig. 9 depicts the TG-DTG curves of K-Ce catalysts at various aging times to soot oxidation with a thermal aging temperature of 600 °C. In Fig. 9, there is no discernible difference in the characteristic temperature of soot oxidation between thermally aged KC-0.2 catalysts and fresh KC-0.2 catalysts. However, the Wmax and Rw indexes are reduced by thermal aging catalysts compared with KC-0.2 fresh catalyst in Fig. 10 . The potassium alkali molten salt is extremely mobile [38] and undergoes complex transformations between orthorhombic and rhombohedral structures accompanied with thermal decomposition after heating [51], which leads to the damage of catalysts active component. At 600 °C thermal aging temperature, there is lesser extent difference of the thermal aging catalysts for soot oxidation performance with different thermal aging times. This result confirms the stability of the KC-0.2 catalyst at temperatures below 600 °C, which is consistent with previous findings [52–54]. 3.3 Catalytic performance of KC-0.2 based mixed catalysts 3.3.1 Oxidation activity of KC-0.2 based mixed catalysts In this section, a series of TG-DTG curves of the oxidation activity of synthesized KC-0.2 based mixed catalysts with four commercial catalysts participating are obtained in 10% O2/90% N2 atmosphere in Fig. 11 . The temperature required for soot oxidation is significantly different when mixed catalysts (a/KC-0.2) are used instead of KC-0.2 catalyzed soot oxidation. However, the DTG curves of PU/(ZrO2/KC-0.2) mixtures clearly shift to lower temperature region when compared to KC-0.2 and other KC-0.2 based catalyst, indicating that the ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst has the highest combustion rate. The evolutions of Wmean, Wmax and Rw during soot oxidation processes over catalysts in various mixed catalysts are presented in Fig. 12 . The Wmean, Wmax and Rw values of ZrO2/KC-0.2 are 1.99%min−1, 15.85%min−1 and 82 × 10 5, respectively. Other mixed catalysts have negative effect, but the ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst has a positive effect. The following is the catalytic activity order of KC-0.2 and KC-0.2 based mixed catalysts: ZrO2/KC-0.2>KC-0.2>TiO2/KC-0.2 > SnO2/KC-0.2 > MnO2/KC-0.2. The ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst outperforms KC-0.2 in terms of catalytic performance, which is most likely due to the Zr element promoting more redox surface sites and oxygen vacancies for the soot oxidation process [55, 56]. Fig. 13 depicts the TG-DTG curves of ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts at various aging times to soot oxidation. In Fig. 13, there is no discernible difference in the characteristic temperature of soot oxidation between thermally aged ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts and fresh ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts. This result shows that ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts are also stable at temperatures lower than 600 °C. 3.3.2 Characterization of as-prepared catalysts To investigate the elemental species and bulk structure on the surface of ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts, XRD patterns and SEM images are performed in Fig. 14 . In Fig. 14(a), compare the diffractograms of KC-0.2 and ZrO2/KC-0.2. The KC-0.2 diffractogram shows the main reflections typical of a fluorite-structured cubic ceria phase, as well as some low-intensity potassium diffraction peaks. The fluorite-structured phase of ZrO2/KC-0.2 is similar, but no obvious potassium peak is detected, indicating that potassium is highly dispersed phases on the catalyst surface or encapsulated by other phases [57, 58]. Also, the ZrO2/KC-0.2 diffractogram displays four small peaks at 31.5°, 34.2°, 50.1° and 54.1°, corresponding to (111), (200), (022) and (003) of lattice faces of ZrO2 (JCPDS 37–1484) [59], respectively. Meanwhile, the slight shift in the d value of plane (111) from 3.1240 for KC-0.2 to 3.1246 for ZrO2/KC-0.2. Fig. 14(b) clearly shows a uniformly distributed ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst surface with no K species detected. The ZrO2/KC-0.2 mixed catalyst has more uniform pores based on textural and morphological properties, which is better for soot combustion. Fig. 15 shows the O1s spectra of KC-0.2 and ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts, both of which can be deconvoluted into three types of oxygen: lattice oxygen (Olat), oxygen vacancy (Ovac) and physically adsorbed oxygen (Opad) [60]. The O1s peaks of ZrO2/KC-0.2 shifted to lower binding energy values compare with KC-0.2, which is due to the Ce component forming a solid solution with the ZrO2 phase [55]. The ZrO2/KC-0.2 mixed catalyst has more oxygen vacancies than the KC-0.2 sample, and the percentage of Ovac/(Olat+Ovac+Opad) is 23.32%. The presence of Zr in the mixed catalyst improves the concentration activity of oxygen and redox surface sites compared to KC-0.2, which is advantageous for soot oxidation. The redox property and activation capability of the as-prepared catalysts further are detected by H2-TPR profiles and O2-TPD profiles in Fig. 16 . Fig. 16(a) compares the H2-TPR profiles of KC-0.2 and ZrO2/KC-0.2. The ZrO2/KC-0.2 profile has two reduction peaks at approximately 429 °C and 593.4 °C, and the KC-0.2 profile has one reduction peaks at approximately 438.5 °C. The peaks at approximately 450 °C are associated to the reduction of Ce4+→Ce3+ [43, 61], and the peaks of ZrO2/KC-0.2 are present at a much lower temperature. The results show that the ZrO2/KC-0.2 has higher reducibility than KC-0.2. Fig. 16(b) shows information for the adsorption behavior and activation capability of ZrO2/KC-0.2 and KC-0.2 toward oxygen species. Both ZrO2/KC-0.2 and KC-0.2 have two oxygen desorption peaks at temperatures below 600 °C, which are appearing in the temperature ranges of 50 °C-200 °C and 200 °C-500 °C, corresponding to weakly physically adsorbed surface oxygen species and chemically adsorbed oxygen on the oxygen vacancies [62], respectively. The physically adsorbed oxygen of ZrO2/KC-0.2 is much weaker compare with KC-0.2, which is well agreement with the consequence of XPS. The chemically adsorbed oxygen on the oxygen vacancies of the ZrO2/KC-0.2 mixed catalyst is visibly larger than KC-0.2 catalyst, which enable ZrO2/KC-0.2 to exhibit a higher catalytic activity. Raman spectra is employed to further confirm the structure of KC-0.2 and ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst in Fig. 17 . Both catalyst materials have a high peak at 463 cm−1, which corresponds to the F2g mode of the CeO2 fluorite-type structure [41, 63], and this is consistent with the XRD results. Furthermore, a shorter peak for ZrO2/KC-0.2 can be detected at around 245 cm−1, which is attributed to the zirconium tetragonal phase [55]. XRD patterns analysis shows that a slight shift in the d value of plane (111) from 3.1240 for KC-0.2 to 3.1246, which combines with Raman spectra further confirms that the ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst formed a solid solution. Thus, the Zr element promotes more redox surface sites and oxygen vacancies, and makes an increasing the actual number of surface active sites where the catalyst is in contact with soot particulates [55, 64, 65]. Moreover, the potassium species can gain the high contact efficiency between the K-Ce catalyst and soot particulates. These improve the low-temperature soot oxidation ability of the ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalysts. 3.4 Reaction mechanism of K-Ce catalysts The reaction mechanism diagram of soot combustion on K-Ce catalysts is shown in Fig. 18 . Generally, two main pathways are involved in the high efficiency catalysis of soot combustion by K-Ce catalysts [37, 38, 42]. The first one involves the interaction of catalysts and soot particulates. In this pathway, the potassium species can gain the high contact efficiency between the K-Ce catalyst and soot particulates by enhancing surface fluidity at the high temperature [54]. The SEM and XRD results have shown that potassium species are highly dispersed on the surface of the K-Ce catalyst (Fig. 2. and. Fig. 3). The second pathway involves the enhance of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The potassium ions enter the CeO2 (Ce4+-Olat structure), the charge compensation effect causes more oxygen vacancies (Ce3+-Ovac structure), and improves the low-temperature soot oxidation ability of the K-Ce catalysts. This is clearly demonstrated by the XPS analysis in Fig. 4. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of K-Ce catalysts have been successfully synthetized using a hydrothermal method and used for catalytic soot complete oxidation. The K-Ce catalysts have high catalytic activity for soot oxidation, particularly the KC-0.2 catalyst, with Wmean, Wmax and Rw , values of 2.02%min−1, 15.29%min−1 and 73 × 10 5, respectively. SEM, XRD and XPS characterizations show that KC-0.2 catalysts have an abundance of surface activity sites and oxygen vacancies for the soot combustion process. In soot/KC-0.2 mixtures, the catalyst proportion should be less than 1:10. The excessive catalysts can prevent the combustion product from diffusing in time, increasing mass transfer resistance. Stability of KC-0.2 is studied by the thermal aging test, and the results show that KC-0.2 has good stability at temperatures lower than 600 °C. To further investigate combinatorial catalysis on soot combustion, KC-0.2 based mixed catalysts with commercial catalysts (ZrO2, TiO2, SnO2, MnO2) participation are successfully synthetized. ZrO2/KC-0.2 catalyst have the better catalytic activity than KC-0.2 catalysts, with Wmean, Wmax and Rw , of 1.99%min−1, 15.85%min−1 and 82 × 10 5, respectively. The analyze of characterizations indicates that the presence of Zr in the mixed catalyst further improves higher concentration activity oxygen and redox surface sites, which are beneficial for soot oxidation. More significantly, this work is offering new insights for designing novel and efficient soot removal catalysts, as well as the theoretical foundation for the development and application of novel catalysts on CDPF. coredata.dc:description: A series of K-Ce catalysts with different K/(K+Ce) molar ratios are successfully prepared by hydrothermal method, to optimize catalyst diesel particlate filter (CDPF) regeneration efficiency of soot elimination. The K-Ce catalyst is an excellent promoter for soot combustion by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and the KC-0.2 catalyst has the best catalytic activity because proper K ions lead to more oxygen vacancies and improve contact efficiency with soot. This result corresponds well to characterization analysis, such as XRD, SEM and XPS. In a 10%O2/90%N2 atmosphere, the KC-0.2 has the highest average mass loss rate (Wmean ), maximum mass loss rate (Wmax ) and combustion stability index (Rw ). The weight ratios of the soot/KC-0.2 mixture are less than 1:10, making catalytic oxidation easier for the soot. Thermal aging in static air at 600 °C is used to investigate the catalytic stability of KC-0.2, and the TGA results show that KC-0.2 has good stability at temperatures lower than 600 °C. Compare to KC-0.2, the KC-0.2 based mixed catalyst with ZrO2 participation is further prepared by mechanical method and has better catalytic activity because the presence of Zr enhances redox surface sites of catalyst. This facilitates the exploration of novel catalysts through combinatorial catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into catalytic activity of K-Ce catalysts and K-Ce based mixed catalysts on diesel soot combustion
